an10.93:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an10.93:1.2: Then the householder Anāthapiṇḍika left Sāvatthī in the middle of the day to see the Buddha.
an10.93:1.4: “It’s the wrong time to see the Buddha,
an10.93:1.6: And it’s the wrong time to see the esteemed mendicants,
an10.93:1.8: Why don’t I visit the monastery of the wanderers of other religions?”
an10.93:2.1: Then he went to the monastery of the wanderers of other religions.
an10.93:2.2: Now at that time, the wanderers of other religions had come together, making an uproar, a colossal racket as they sat and talked about all kinds of low topics.
an10.93:2.3: They saw Anāthapiṇḍika coming off in the distance,
an10.93:2.5: “Be quiet, good fellows, don’t make a sound.
an10.93:2.6: The householder Anāthapiṇḍika, a disciple of the ascetic Gotama, is coming into our monastery.
an10.93:2.7: He is included among the white-clothed lay disciples of the ascetic Gotama, who is residing in Sāvatthī.
an10.93:2.8: Such venerables like the quiet, are educated to be quiet, and praise the quiet.
an10.93:2.9: Hopefully if he sees that our assembly is quiet he’ll see fit to approach.”
an10.93:3.1: Then those wanderers of other religions fell silent.
an10.93:3.2: Then Anāthapiṇḍika went up to them, and exchanged greetings with those wanderers.
an10.93:3.3: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. The wanderers said to him,
an10.93:3.4: “Tell us, householder, what is the view of the ascetic Gotama?”
an10.93:3.5: “Sirs, I don’t know all his views.”
an10.93:4.1: “Well then, since it seems you don’t know all the views of the ascetic Gotama,
an10.93:4.2: tell us, what are the views of the mendicants?”
an10.93:4.3: “Sirs, I don’t know all the mendicants’ views.”
an10.93:5.1: “Well then, since it seems you don’t know all the views of the ascetic Gotama or of the mendicants,
an10.93:5.2: tell us, householder, what is your view?”
an10.93:5.3: “Sirs, it’s not hard for me to explain what my views are.
an10.93:5.4: But please, let the venerables explain their own convictions first. Afterwards it won’t be hard for me to explain my views.”
an10.93:6.1: When he said this, one of the wanderers said to him,
an10.93:6.2: “The cosmos is eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile.
an10.93:7.2: “The cosmos is not eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile.
an10.93:8.4: “The soul and the body are one and the same …” …
an10.93:8.5: “The soul is one thing, the body another …” …
an10.93:8.6: “A realized one still exists after death …” …
an10.93:8.7: “A realized one no longer exists after death …” …
an10.93:8.8: “A realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death …” …
an10.93:8.9: “A Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death. This is the only truth, anything else is futile.
an10.93:9.1: When this was said, Anāthapiṇḍika said this,
an10.93:9.2: “Sirs, regarding the venerable who said this:
an10.93:9.3: ‘The cosmos is eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile.
an10.93:9.5: This view of his has either arisen from his own irrational application of mind, or is conditioned by what someone else says.
an10.93:9.6: But that view is created, conditioned, chosen, dependently originated.
an10.93:9.7: Whatever is created, conditioned, chosen, and dependently originated is impermanent.
an10.93:9.9: What he clings to and holds to is just suffering.
an10.93:10.1: Regarding the venerable who said this:
an10.93:10.2: ‘The cosmos is not eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile.
an10.93:10.4: This view of his has either arisen from his own irrational application of mind, or is conditioned by what someone else says.
an10.93:10.5: But that view is created, conditioned, chosen, dependently originated.
an10.93:10.6: Whatever is created, conditioned, chosen, and dependently originated is impermanent.
an10.93:10.8: What he clings to and holds to is just suffering.
an10.93:11.1: Regarding the venerable who said this:
an10.93:11.4: ‘The soul and the body are one and the same …’ …
an10.93:11.5: ‘The soul is one thing, the body another …’ …
an10.93:11.6: ‘A realized one still exists after death …’ …
an10.93:11.7: ‘A realized one no longer exists after death …’ …
an10.93:11.8: ‘A realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death …’ …
an10.93:11.9: ‘A Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death. This is the only truth, anything else is futile.
an10.93:11.11: This view of his has either arisen from his own irrational application of mind, or is conditioned by what someone else says.
an10.93:11.12: But that view is created, conditioned, chosen, dependently originated.
an10.93:11.13: Whatever is created, conditioned, chosen, and dependently originated is impermanent.
an10.93:11.15: What he clings to and holds to is just suffering.”
an10.93:12.1: When he said this the wanderers said to him,
an10.93:12.2: “Householder, we’ve each explained our own convictions.
an10.93:12.3: Tell us, householder, what is your view?”
an10.93:12.4: “Sirs, whatever is created, conditioned, chosen, and dependently originated is impermanent.
an10.93:12.6: And what’s suffering is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.
an10.93:13.1: “Householder, whatever is created, conditioned, chosen, and dependently originated is impermanent.
an10.93:13.3: What you cling to and hold to is just suffering.”
an10.93:14.1: “Sirs, whatever is created, conditioned, chosen, and dependently originated is impermanent.
an10.93:14.3: And I’ve truly seen clearly with right wisdom that what’s suffering is not mine, I am not this, it’s not my self.
an10.93:14.4: And I truly understand the escape beyond that.”
an10.93:15.1: When this was said, those wanderers sat silent, dismayed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.
an10.93:15.2: Seeing this, Anāthapiṇḍika got up from his seat. He went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and informed the Buddha of all they had discussed.
an10.93:15.4: That’s how you should legitimately and completely refute those futile men from time to time.”
an10.93:16.1: Then the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired the householder Anāthapiṇḍika with a Dhamma talk,
an10.93:16.2: after which Anāthapiṇḍika got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha before leaving.
an10.93:17.1: Then, not long after Anāthapiṇḍika had left, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
an10.93:17.2: “Mendicants, even a mendicant who has ordained for a hundred years in this teaching and training would legitimately and completely refute those wanderers of other religions just as the householder Anāthapiṇḍika did.”
